articles.headline: The Divided States of Health Care
articles.snippet: Those who lack health insurance are far more likely to live in Republican states, according to a Census survey.
articles.abstract: Those who lack health insurance are far more likely to live in Republican states, according to a Census survey.
articles.lead_paragraph: Where do those without health insurance live?

articles.headline: Crisis Leaves Europe in Slow Lane
articles.snippet: As Asia and the U.S. emerge from the global economic crisis, Europe appears likely to be the world’s laggard.
articles.abstract: As Asia and the U.S. emerge from the global economic crisis, Europe appears likely to be the world’s laggard.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Two years ago, Europe was growing more rapidly than the United States, and the Old Continent finally seemed prepared to tackle longstanding economic challenges like rigid labor markets, runaway government spending and a rapidly aging population.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Matthew Saltmarsh

articles.headline: Abortion Foes Tell of Their Journey to the Streets
articles.snippet: An assertive minority of the anti-abortion movement, street activists use provocative tactics that tend to attract conflict.
articles.abstract: An assertive minority of the anti-abortion movement, street activists use provocative tactics that tend to attract conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: OWOSSO, Mich.  Action means many things to abortion opponents. Lobbyists and fund-raisers fight for the cause in marble hallways; volunteers at crisis pregnancy centers try to dissuade the pregnant on cozy sofas.

articles.headline: Have Banks No Shame?
articles.snippet: Lobbies representing the banking industry are opposing the creation of a consumer financial protection agency.
articles.abstract: Lobbies representing the banking industry are opposing the creation of a consumer financial protection agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I asked Simon Johnson, the former International Monetary Fund economist, now a prominent critic of the banking industry, what he thought the banks owed the country after all the government bailouts.

articles.headline: New Way to Tap Gas May Expand Global Supplies
articles.snippet: Huge new reserves of natural gas, especially in Europe, could alter the political landscape for energy, experts say.
articles.abstract: Huge new reserves of natural gas, especially in Europe, could alter the political landscape for energy, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY  A new technique that tapped previously inaccessible supplies of natural gas in the United States is spreading to the rest of the world, raising hopes of a huge expansion in global reserves of the cleanest fossil fuel.

articles.headline: Debt Trips Up Hinckley, Venerable Yacht Maker
articles.snippet: Hinckley Yachts, known for beautiful sailboats and sleek powerboats, lost business when the economy faltered, but debt made its problems even worse.
articles.abstract: Hinckley Yachts, known for beautiful sailboats and sleek powerboats, lost business when the economy faltered, but debt made its problems even worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTHWEST HARBOR, Me.  David Rockefeller Sr. ordered a new boat last year, a $3 million 55-foot powerboat.

articles.headline: Panel Says Obama Plan Won’t Slow Foreclosures
articles.snippet: The Congressional Oversight Panel, created last year to keep tabs on taxpayer bailout funds, said the Obama administration’s program would prevent fewer than half of predicted foreclosures.
articles.abstract: The Congressional Oversight Panel, created last year to keep tabs on taxpayer bailout funds, said the Obama administration’s program would prevent fewer than half of predicted foreclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after the Obama administration proclaimed significant progress in its effort to spare troubled homeowners from foreclosure, an oversight panel on Friday sharply criticized the program and declared it would leave millions of Americans vulnerable to losing their homes.

articles.headline: Pakistan Retakes Army Headquarters; Hostages Freed
articles.snippet: Commandos rescued 42 hostages who were held by militants inside Pakistan’s military headquarters, but three hostages were killed.
articles.abstract: Commandos rescued 42 hostages who were held by militants inside Pakistan’s military headquarters, but three hostages were killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani commandos rescued 42 hostages early Sunday who were held by militants inside the nation’s military headquarters, after gunmen dressed in army fatigues stormed the building in a brazen attack 18 hours earlier, according to the chief army spokesman.

articles.headline: A Dogged Taliban Chief Rebounds, Vexing U.S.
articles.snippet: Mullah Muhammad Omar’s prospects seemed bleak in 2001. Now, he leads an insurgency that has gained ground in much of Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Mullah Muhammad Omar’s prospects seemed bleak in 2001. Now, he leads an insurgency that has gained ground in much of Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In late 2001, Mullah Muhammad Omar’s prospects seemed utterly bleak. The ill-educated, one-eyed leader of the Taliban had fled on a motorbike after his fighters were swiftly routed by the Americans invading Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Failures of Small Banks Grow, Straining F.D.I.C.
articles.snippet: After the rescue of banks considered too big to fail, smaller ones near a grim milestone: the 100th failure of 2009.
articles.abstract: After the rescue of banks considered too big to fail, smaller ones near a grim milestone: the 100th failure of 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after Washington rescued the banks considered too big to fail, the ones deemed too small to save are approaching a grim milestone: the 100th bank failure of 2009.

articles.headline: Whispering to Rottweilers, and to C.E.O.’s
articles.snippet: Cesar Millan, the “Dog Whisperer,” is a cultural icon, commanding respect wherever he goes. He has helped scores of celebrities and moguls in dealing with their pets.
articles.abstract: Cesar Millan, the “Dog Whisperer,” is a cultural icon, commanding respect wherever he goes. He has helped scores of celebrities and moguls in dealing with their pets.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

articles.headline: Citigroup Hires Mr. Inside
articles.snippet: Citigroup has raised some hackles by hiring a longtime Washington insider who critics say exacerbated the savings and loan crisis.
articles.abstract: Citigroup has raised some hackles by hiring a longtime Washington insider who critics say exacerbated the savings and loan crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALL of the nation’s major banks have a raft of Washington lobbyists, and with good reason. For people accustomed to dealing with numbers on Wall Street, the nation’s capital can seem impossibly complex.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: When Bond Ratings Get Stale
articles.snippet: Owning bonds whose ratings haven’t been reviewed for decades is a risky proposition.
articles.abstract: Owning bonds whose ratings haven’t been reviewed for decades is a risky proposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE utter failings of our nation’s credit rating agencies  you know the drill: repeatedly slapping triple-A ratings on piles of dubious mortgage securities  were central to the financial crisis. And anything-goes ratings from Fitch, Moody’s Investors Service and Standard & Poor’s have left investors around the world with trillions in losses.

articles.headline: The Big Tests for Letterman Are Still Ahead
articles.snippet: Public opinion has been kind but could turn if the host is dragged into court. And will this debacle undercut his comedy?
articles.abstract: Public opinion has been kind but could turn if the host is dragged into court. And will this debacle undercut his comedy?
articles.lead_paragraph: David Letterman walked onto the stage to a swell of welcome Friday night, just as he has for more than 27 years. He sheepishly basked in the routine adoration, but then asked:

articles.headline: Training to Climb an Everest of Digital Data
articles.snippet: Google and I.B.M. are offering help to universities to get students to cope with vast amounts of data.
articles.abstract: Google and I.B.M. are offering help to universities to get students to cope with vast amounts of data.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  It is a rare criticism of elite American university students that they do not think big enough. But that is exactly the complaint from some of the largest technology companies and the federal government.

articles.headline: Special Issues a Bright Spot for Magazines
articles.snippet: For magazines, print advertising is in poor shape right now, but special issues seem to be the one thing attracting ad dollars.
articles.abstract: For magazines, print advertising is in poor shape right now, but special issues seem to be the one thing attracting ad dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: In this dreary advertising climate, when ESPN The Magazine wanted to draw some attention to itself, it chose a tactic favored by the Lindsay Lohans of the world: flash a little skin.

articles.headline: On Cluttered Ballots of India, Families Proliferate
articles.snippet: Political dynasties have grown so rapidly that many analysts say nepotism is corroding the democratic system.
articles.abstract: Political dynasties have grown so rapidly that many analysts say nepotism is corroding the democratic system.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMRAVATI, India  Rajendra Shekhawat, nicely polished in a pressed white shirt and neatly parted hair, his face sunburned from campaigning in the south Indian sun, says he is running for office as a common man. His pink cheeks suggest otherwise, though, since common men in India usually toil outdoors without requiring sunscreen.

articles.headline: Debate Over Effects of Leno’s Show
articles.snippet: Critics of NBC’s move to bring Jay Leno to 10 p.m. cite a negative effect on other programs, but the network says it is too early to judge.
articles.abstract: Critics of NBC’s move to bring Jay Leno to 10 p.m. cite a negative effect on other programs, but the network says it is too early to judge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks into a new season, the talk of television is the Leno effect  and whether it is hazardous to NBC’s health.

articles.headline: Civilian Goals Largely Unmet in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Obama administration officials say the U.S. is falling far short of the president’s goals to fight corruption, create a functioning government and train a police force.
articles.abstract: Obama administration officials say the U.S. is falling far short of the president’s goals to fight corruption, create a functioning government and train a police force.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Even as President Obama leads an intense debate over whether to send more troops to Afghanistan, administration officials say the United States is falling far short of his goals to fight the country’s endemic corruption, create a functioning government and legal system and train a police force currently riddled with incompetence.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Mark Landler

articles.headline: U.S. Can’t Trace Foreign Visitors on Expired Visas
articles.snippet: Despite repeated mandates from Congress, the U.S. still has no reliable system for verifying that foreign visitors on temporary visas have left the country.
articles.abstract: Despite repeated mandates from Congress, the U.S. still has no reliable system for verifying that foreign visitors on temporary visas have left the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS  Eight years after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and despite repeated mandates from Congress, the United States still has no reliable system for verifying that foreign visitors have left the country.
articles.byline: By James C. McKinley Jr. and Julia Preston

articles.headline: Fox’s Volley With Obama Intensifying
articles.snippet: Attacking the news media is a time-honored White House tactic but the Obama administration has narrowed its sights to the Fox News Channel.
articles.abstract: Attacking the news media is a time-honored White House tactic but the Obama administration has narrowed its sights to the Fox News Channel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Attacking the news media is a time-honored White House tactic but to an unusual degree, the Obama administration has narrowed its sights to one specific organization, the Fox News Channel, calling it, in essence, part of the political opposition.

articles.headline: Two State Races May Put Lens on Obama
articles.snippet: The governor’s races in Virginia and New Jersey loom as early if imprecise tests of the president and his policies.
articles.abstract: The governor’s races in Virginia and New Jersey loom as early if imprecise tests of the president and his policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEESBURG, Va.  When President Obama captured the White House nearly a year ago, his victory in Virginia was, for many Democrats, one of the most heartening moments of the night.

articles.headline: Two Americans Are Awarded Nobel in Economics
articles.snippet: Oliver E. Williamson shared the honor with Elinor Ostrom, the first woman to win the prize for economics.
articles.abstract: Oliver E. Williamson shared the honor with Elinor Ostrom, the first woman to win the prize for economics.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded on Monday to two American social scientists for their work in describing the numerous relationships within a company or among companies and individuals that shape market behavior.
